1.verse: God Calls and Jonah Runs - The ·LORD spoke his word [word of the LORD came] to Jonah son of Amittai:

2.verse: “Get up, go to the great city of Nineveh [the capital of Assyria; Gen. 10:11, 12; 2 Kin. 19:36], and ·preach [cry out] against it, because ·I see the evil things they do [its wickedness has come to my attention/up before me].”

3.verse: But Jonah got up to run away from the LORD by going to Tarshish [probably Tartessos in southwest Spain, the opposite direction from Nineveh]. He went to the city of Joppa, where he found a ship that was going to the city of Tarshish. Jonah paid for the trip and went aboard, planning to go to Tarshish to run away from the LORD.

4.verse: But the LORD ·sent [hurled] a great wind on the sea, which made the sea so stormy that the ship was in danger of breaking apart.

5.verse: The sailors were afraid, and each man cried to his own god. They began throwing the cargo from the ship into the sea to make the ship lighter. But Jonah had gone down far inside the ship to lie down, and he fell fast asleep.

6.verse: The captain of the ship came and said, “Why are you sleeping? Get up and pray to your god! Maybe your god will ·pay attention to [take notice of] us, and we won’t die!”

7.verse: Then the men said to each other, “Let’s throw lots to see who caused these troubles to happen to us.” When they threw lots, the lot ·showed that the trouble had happened because of [singled out; fell upon] Jonah.

8.verse: Then they said to him, “Tell us, who caused our trouble? What is your job? Where do you come from? What is your country? Who are your people?”

9.verse: Then Jonah said to them, “I am a Hebrew. I ·fear [worship] the LORD, the God of heaven, who made the sea and the land [Gen. 1].”

10.verse: The men were very afraid, and they asked Jonah, “What terrible thing did you do?” (They knew he was running away from the LORD because he had told them.)

11.verse: Since the wind and the waves of the sea were becoming much stronger, they said to him, “What should we do to you to make the sea calm down for us?”

12.verse: Jonah said to them, “Pick me up, and throw me into the sea, and then it will calm down. I know it is my fault that this great storm has come on you.”

13.verse: Instead, the men ·tried [dug in] to row the ship back to the land, but they could not, because the sea was becoming more stormy.

14.verse: Jonah’s Punishment - So the men cried to the LORD, “LORD, please don’t let us die because of this man’s life; please don’t ·think we are [hold us] guilty of ·killing an innocent person [innocent blood]. LORD, you have caused all this to happen; you wanted it this way.”

15.verse: So they picked up Jonah and threw him into the sea, and the sea ·became calm [ceased raging].

16.verse: Then they began to fear the LORD very much; they offered a sacrifice to the LORD and made ·promises [vows] to him.

17.verse: The LORD ·caused [appointed; provided] a big fish to swallow Jonah, and Jonah was ·inside [in the belly of] the fish three days and three nights.

1.verse: While Jonah was ·inside [in the belly/innards of] the fish, he prayed to the LORD his God and said,

2.verse: “When I was in ·danger [distress], I called to the LORD, and he answered me. ·I was about to die [From the belly of Sheol; the place of the dead], so I cried to you, and you heard my voice.

3.verse: You threw me into the ·sea [ocean depths; deep], down, down into the ·deep [heart of the] sea. The ·water [flood] ·was all around [engulfed] me, and your ·powerful [surging; billowing] waves ·flowed [swept] over me.

4.verse: I said, ‘I was ·driven out of your presence [banished from your sight], ·but I hope to see [yet I will look toward] your Holy Temple again.’

5.verse: The waters of the sea closed around my ·throat [or soul]. The deep sea ·was all around [surrounded; closed in on] me; seaweed was wrapped around my head.

6.verse: When I ·went [sank] down to ·where the mountains of the sea start to rise [the roots of the mountains], ·I thought I was locked in this prison [the earth’s bars held me] forever, but you ·saved me [brought up my life] from the pit of death, LORD my God.

7.verse: “When my life ·had almost gone [was slipping/fainting away], I remembered the LORD. ·I prayed [My prayer went up] to you, ·and you heard my prayers in [in] your Holy Temple.

8.verse: “People who ·worship [cling to] ·useless [worthless; false] idols ·give up their loyalty to you [or forfeit the mercy/lovingkindness that is theirs].

9.verse: But ·I will praise and thank you while I [with a voice of thanksgiving I will] give sacrifices to you, and I will ·keep my promises to you [pay what I have vowed]. Salvation comes from the LORD!”

10.verse: Then the LORD spoke to the fish, and the fish ·threw up [vomited] Jonah onto the dry land.

1.verse: God Calls and Jonah Obeys - The ·LORD spoke his word [word of the LORD came] to Jonah ·again [a second time] and said,

2.verse: “Get up, go to the great city Nineveh [1:2], and ·preach [cry out] to it what I tell you to say.”

3.verse: So Jonah obeyed the LORD and got up and went to Nineveh. It was a very large city; just to walk ·across it [or through it all] took a person three days.

4.verse: After Jonah had entered the city and walked for one day, he preached to the people, saying, “After forty days, Nineveh will be ·destroyed [overthrown]!”

5.verse: The people of Nineveh believed God. They ·announced that they would fast [called for/decreed a fast], and they put on ·rough cloth [burlap; sackcloth; to show their sorrow and repentance]. All the people in the city did this, from the ·most important to the least important [greatest to the least].

6.verse: When the king of Nineveh heard this news, he got up from his throne, took off his robe, and covered himself with ·rough cloth [burlap; sackcloth] and sat in ashes [to show sorrow and repentance].

7.verse: He ·sent this announcement [issued a proclamation] through Nineveh: By ·command [the decree] of the king and his ·important men [nobles]: No person or animal, herd or flock, will be allowed to taste anything. Do not let them eat food or drink water.

8.verse: But every person and animal should be covered with ·rough cloth [burlap; sackcloth], and people should ·cry loudly [pray earnestly] to God. Everyone must turn away from evil living and stop doing ·harm [violence] all the time.

9.verse: Who knows? Maybe God will ·change his mind [relent]. Maybe he will ·stop being angry [turn from his fierce anger], and then we will not ·die [perish].

10.verse: When God saw what the people did, that they stopped doing evil, he ·changed his mind [relented] and did not carry out the ·destruction [disaster; punishment] he had threatened.

1.verse: God’s Mercy Makes Jonah Angry - But this made Jonah very unhappy, and he became angry.

2.verse: He prayed to the LORD, “When I was still in my own country ·this is [isn’t this…?] what I said would happen, and that is why I quickly ran away to Tarshish [1:3]. I knew that you are a God who is ·kind [gracious] and ·shows mercy [compassionate]. ·You don’t become angry quickly […slow to anger], and you ·have great love [abound in lovingkindness/mercy; Ex. 34:6–7]. I knew you would ·choose not to cause [relent from doing] harm.

3.verse: So now I ask you, LORD, please ·kill me [take my life]. It is better for me to die than to live.”

4.verse: Then the LORD said, “Do you think it is right for you to be angry?”

5.verse: Jonah went out and sat down east of the city. There he made a shelter for himself and sat in the shade, waiting to see what would happen to the city.

6.verse: The LORD made a ·plant [gourd] grow quickly up over Jonah, which gave him shade and ·helped him to be more comfortable [eased his discomfort]. Jonah was very pleased to have the ·plant [gourd].

7.verse: But the next day when the sun rose, God sent a worm to attack the ·plant [gourd] so that it ·died [dried up; withered].

8.verse: As the sun rose higher in the sky, God sent a very hot east wind to blow, and the sun ·became so hot [beat down] on Jonah’s head that he became ·very weak [faint] and wished he were dead. He said, “It is better for me to die than to live.”

9.verse: But God said to Jonah, “Do you think it is right for you to be angry about the ·plant [gourd]?” Jonah answered, “It is right for me to be angry! I am so angry I could die!”

10.verse: And the LORD said, “You ·are so concerned [have pity] for that ·plant [gourd] even though you did nothing to make it grow. It appeared ·one day [overnight], and ·the next day [overnight] it died.

11.verse: Then shouldn’t I ·show concern [have pity] for the great city Nineveh, which has more than one hundred twenty thousand people who do not know ·right from wrong [their right hand from their left], and ·many animals [much cattle], too?”
